paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Does TRAPPIST-1 b, an Earth-sized rocky planet on a short, tidally locked orbit around an M dwarf, retain any atmosphere under strong stellar irradiation?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: JWST MIRI Phase-Curve Spectroscopy
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: Thermal phase-resolved spectra spanning full orbital period
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Low-resolution spectroscopic observations from JWST Mid-Infrared Instrument covering the orbital phase curve of TRAPPIST-1 b, sensitive to thermal emission and spectral structure around the 15 um CO2 band.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Bare-Rock No-Atmosphere Model
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Theoretical model representing a planet with no atmosphere, assuming minimal heat redistribution where dayside absorbed energy is immediately re-radiated, serving as the baseline comparator for atmospheric detection.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-Rich Atmosphere Retrieval
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: Atmosphere-bearing scenario with greenhouse gas absorption
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Retrieval model assuming an atmosphere with significant CO2 content, predicting greenhouse warming and heat redistribution that would modify both phase curve amplitude and spectral features.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-Rich Atmosphere Retrieval
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmosphere model with oxidized composition providing weaker CO2 signature constraints, representing a chemically distinct atmospheric possibility consistent with rocky planet evolution around M dwarfs.

major_limitations: This is a single-planet study and does not establish atmospheric prevalence across all M-dwarf rocky planets in the TRAPPIST-1 system or beyond.

Retrieval assumptions regarding circulation patterns, opacity priors, and cloud treatment significantly affect quantitative posterior estimates and should be interpreted with appropriate uncertainty margins.
Stellar variability from the active M dwarf host and potential instrument systematics could bias detection of weak spectral features near the detection threshold.
Night-side constraints are substantially weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset, limiting complete characterization of day-night heat transport.
